question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
Prove that $\displaystyle 1729 = 7 \cdot 13 \cdot 19$ is a Carmichael
number.

(Hint\begin{align*}\displaystyle 1728 = 6 \cdot 288 = 12 \cdot 144 = 18 \cdot 96\end{align*})
sols:
We proceed using the hints. Clearly 1729 is square free so it suffices
to check that for each prime divisor, we have that $(p-1)\mid(n-1)$. We
proceed mechanically

\begin{align*}
(7-1) &= 6 \mid 1728 \\
(13-1) &= 12 \mid 1728 \\
(19-1) &= 18 \mid 1728 \end{align*}

And all of these are true since
$\displaystyle 1728 = 12^{3} = 2^{6}3^{3}$. Hence 1729 is a Carmichael
number.
hints:
A Carmichael number is a composite number \emph{n} which satisfies

$\displaystyle b^{n-1} \equiv 1 \mod{n}$

for all integers with $\displaystyle \gcd(b,n) = 1$.

Recall Korselt's criterion which states that a positive composite
integer \emph{n} is a Carmichael number if and only if \emph{n} is
square free and for all prime divisors \emph{p} of \emph{n}, it is true
that $\displaystyle (p-1) \mid (n-1)$
